frame.name: FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy
frame.definition:
<def-root> A <fen>Persuader</fen> attempts through language to get an <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>, that has not happened or been settled yet, is or is not legitimate. The <fen>Polarity</fen> is either expressed as a meaningful subcategorized preposition or is positive and incorporated in the LU. There is no implication that the <fen>Addressee</fen> ends up believing the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> to be legitimate. <ex></ex>
Distinctions with other frames:
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>FR_Attempt_suasion.veracity</frframe>: in FR_Attempt_suasion.veracity, the Persuader wants the Cognizer to believe the State_of_affairs is true, whereas in FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy, the Persuader wants them to think it is legitimate.
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>FR_Attempt_suasion.to_do</frframe>: in FR_Attempt_suasion.to_do, the Persuader wants the Cognizer to perform an Action, whereas in FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy, the Persuader wants the Addressee to think some State_of_affairs is legitimate, but not necessarily do anything to make it happen. Also, FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy is necessarily done through language whereas this is not the case for FR_Attempt_suasion.to_do.
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>FR_Attempt_supported_suasion</frframe>: LUs of Attempt_suasion.legitimacy do not allow any local realization of a Support for the Attempt_suasion, whereas in FR_Attempt_supported_suasion, all LUs do. In that frame, the semantics assigned to the supported State_of_affairs (state of affairs deemed legitimate or true, or even action to be performed) are also underspecified.
<ex></ex> ≠ <frframe>FR_Justifying</frframe>: In FR_Justifying, the Action or State_of_affairs the Communicator is trying to show as legitimate is considered to be known as true and to have happened or at least been decided already, whereas in FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy, the Persuader is trying to present a future action or state of affairs as legitimate.
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>FR_Taking_side</frframe>: FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy's LUs lexically entail the idea of the Persuader wanting to convince an Addressee of the legitimacy of the State_of_affairs. This is not the case for FR_Taking_sides, in which, unlike FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy's, the LUs do not all allow for a locally realized Addressee.
<ex></ex> <asf>Relation to fndata-1.5</asf> : Results from the splitting of Attempt_suasion into four frames, FR_Attempt_suasion.legitimacy, <frframe>FR_Attempt_suasion.to_do</frframe>, <frframe>FR_Attempt_suasion.veracity</frframe> and <frframe>FR_Attempt_supported_suasion</frframe>. This four-way split is based on the nature of the <fen>Content</fen> role and its semantics for the first three (respectively state of affairs to be thought legitimate, Action to be executed or Content to be thought true), and on the possibility of a locally realized Support for <frframe>FR_Attempt_supported_suasion</frframe>.</def-root>

FE.name: State_of_affairs
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Persuader</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is legitimate.</def-root>

FE.name: Polarity
FE.definition: <def-root> the <fen>Polarity</fen> is whether the Speaker is in favor or against the State_of_affairs. It can be either incorporated in the LUs of this frame, or expressed by a preposition that is subcategorized, but whose meaning is not totally empty. <ex>FR-EX: Comment peut-on sérieusement <t>plaider</t> <fex name="Polarity">contre</fex> l'équité fiscale?</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is conveyed.<ex>Jan <t>argued</t> <fex name="Medium">in writing</fex> that the evidence was inadmissable.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Persuader
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Persuader</fen> presents the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.<ex><fex name="Persuader">Jan</fex> <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Addressee
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Addressee</fen> is the entity before whom the <fen>Persuader</fen> presents a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>. <ex>Jan <t>argued</t> <fex name="Addressee">to the court</fex> that the evidence was inadmissable.</ex></def-root>
